title: Tuesday, 6th August 2019

Sirius Minerals Plc (the "Company") has decided to suspend the proposed offer by its wholly owned subsidiary of $500 million of senior secured notes due 2027 previously announced by RNS on 19 July 2019 due to current market conditions.

The Company intends to revisit the market when conditions have improved later this quarter.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Given the current market turmoil (e.g. the escalating US-China dispute), Sirius has decided to suspend for now its proposed offer of US$500m of senior secured notes (‘Initial Bonds’) due 2027. The company intends to relaunch the offer “when conditions have improved later this quarter”. In practice, we expect that this would be sometime in September 2019.

To re-cap, Sirius is now at the crucial juncture of its US$3.8bn Stage 2 financing package for the construction of its paradigm-shifting North Yorkshire polyhalite project in England.

Sirius successfully completed the first phase (henceforth ‘Stage 2a’) of this package earlier in 2019, raising US$425m of equity and US$400m of convertible bonds.
The current stage, the US$3.0bn ‘Senior Debt Event’ (‘Stage 2b’), involves: raising at least US$500m of Initial Bonds or other acceptable financing; and entering into a US$2.5bn Revolving Credit Facility (RCF). Each of the senior debt components would be conditional (amongst other things) on the other being available. The Event is also a condition for the released of escrowed Stage 2a convertible proceeds.
We expect the Senior Debt Event to catalyse a major re-rating of the shares, as it is in our view effectively the key to unlocking Sirius’s vast value potential. Beyond that, while Sirius would still be some years from becoming cash generative, an investment in the company should become progressively de-risked and enjoy significant value uplift as it advances towards production, we believe.

GBKrona Hola
BE11:13am

And Liberum.

BE11:13am

Sirius has suspended bond issue until market conditions stabilise, we think it will likely e-launch at the beginning of September. Progress will continue at site. Cash reserves have been guided to the end of September, although there is likely to scope to extend slighty longer if financing discussions push up against that deadline. The convertible bond funds in Escrow and the RCF commitment letter are effectively valid until the end of October. Clearly not the desired outcome, but market volatility since Friday has clearly not helped discussions with bond investors. Retain BUY, PT 40p.

11:14 am

Only Cazenove seems prepared to mention the possibility that market conditions won't be significantly improved for single-project paper at north of 13%.

BE11:15am

The HY tranche is the critical path for the project insomuch as it releases the CB and RCF facility and removes the funding overhang. As we noted at the Q2 result (here), we believe there is an elevated risk profile evident for equity-holders until completion of the HY tranche, given shareholders are, in essence, shouldering the full burden of project financing risk. We note that the RCF commitment lasts until October and the CB funds are held in escrow until January. Furthermore, we see two negative outcomes from today’s release (i) the market will now inevitably price in an ‘alternative’ funding scenario which could include an additional equity call; and (ii) uncertainty whether there is sufficient near-term liquidity to deploy capital at the required cadence and, if so, to what extent this is a risk to project schedule (i.e. valuation implications). Prior guidance was that SXX had sufficient funding until the end of September before liquidity would be an impediment.

BE11:26am

Rehabilitation. After the torrid news flow that began in 1H16 and continued through February 2019 (KC-46 charges totalling £160m) the rehabilitation of Cobham in terms of sentiment had barely begun until the weeks before the 1H19 results. In terms of Cobham's financial position, we believed the Group had returned to strength, but the perceived risk remained elevated, in our view. The 1H19 results saw us enjoy a good old-fashioned 'beat and raise' on EBIT and more good news on FCF. Cobham's commentary also seemed more positive. In isolation, we venture Cobham's rehabilitation would be underway. Of course, Advent's offer of 165p per share in cash essentially saw that rehabilitation occur in a matter of minutes.

Rejuvenation. Our DCF valuation is now 168p so Advent's offer of 165p cannot be sneezed at. Cobham was, however, also beginning its rejuvenation in announcing a strategic review of CAVS Australia had commenced. We look at CAVS Australia in some detail here. Determining a valuation proved quite challenging; the business may earn no EBIT, but has EBITDA of £20-25m. We figure much may hinge on the view of the renewal - or not - of the Sentinel contract in FY21. We venture a valuation of £150-200m for CAVS Australia.

PBateman wow @crackle!
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I'll take a look at the FT link... :)
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Reward and risk. Advent's offer circumvents the remaining risk on KC-46, albeit we see KC-46 as much as an opportunity as a risk. It also avoids execution risk at CAES which did not distinguish itself in 1H19 even if Cobham's commentary was quite encouraging. The commentary on the Aviator S SATCOM system in CCC also sounded quite positive. When combined with further strong FCF, the strategic review of CAVS Australia, and a balance sheet we deem overtly strong, we venture the downside risk at 130p should Advent's offer not prevail.

Unfinished business. We remain optimistic that CAES will enjoy further good organic growth in revenue and a 30% or higher drop-through from those higher sales to EBIT. The snag is we have nothing to point to in terms of the performance of CAES in FY18 or 1H19, other than order intake. We have been asked many times what Cobham might know that other observers are unaware of. Our reply is that we have looked hard again and have found nothing; almost the opposite, in fact. Perhaps Cobham's business portfolio would have had to change significantly over time and the proceeds and already strong balance sheet astutely deployed over the next 12-24 months to generate a valuation significantly above 165p per share. We do not underestimate how challenging a proposition that may be - or appear to be. Nonetheless, if Advent's offer prevails, we believe a sense of there being unfinished business will exist. Given our PT of 168p, we downgrade from Buy to Hold.

BE11:27am

As for Meggitt, H1 better but guidance broadly unchanged.

Meggitt PLC (MGGT:LSE): Last: 601.00, up 29.8 (+5.22%), High: 606.20, Low: 584.40, Volume: 1.16m
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Here's Sandy again.

BE11:28am

1H19 Sales and EBIT represent 49% and 41% respectively of the FY19 company-sourced consensus. In FY18, the split of sales was 1H 46% and 2H 54% and the EBIT split was 1H 41% and 2H 59%. The EBIT skew typically arises in Aircraft Braking, now part of the Airframe Systems division. FY19 revenue guidance is raised from +3-5% to +4-6% with EBIT margin guidance maintained at 17.7-18.2%.
1Q19 results in brief. Curiously, we have found no clear consensus data for 1H19 (Meggitt is not unique in this, so the mystery deepens) other than Visible Alpha. Group sales rose from £952.2m to £1,071.0m (Cons £1,027.3m) with organic growth of 9%. The latter is the same as the 9% growth reported in 1Q19, but the 1Q18 comparative was +5% while the 2Q18 comparative was +13% so we figure the 1H19 outcome is good. Group EBIT rose from £150.8m to £161m (Cons £161.8m). Group order intake rose from £1,087.2m to £1,193.0m, organic growth of 7% (1H18 order intake +24% organically due to multi-year orders in Defence and a Wizz Air aftermarket contract). Group free cash flow rose from £27.1m to £47m, quite encouraging given capex was guided to increase significantly. The dividend was increased by 4.7% from 5.3p to 5.55p.

cracklenpop @PBateman And watch in real time as the media hunt as a pack, devouring all easyjet press officers before them
BE11:29am

New look. This is the first report under the new divisional structure, a change that we never quite caught up with. The absence of a clear consensus suggests we might not be alone. Airframe Systems revenue rose from £449.6m to £498.3m, organic growth of 6% and EBIT rose from £96.6m to £103m. Engine Systems revenue rose from £125.3m to £159.2m (+21% organically), but EBIT fell from £10.4m to £4.7m. The grounding of the 737 MAX does not appear to have had a marked impact here.
Energy & Equipment revenue rose from £167.3m to £191.5m (+9% organically) and EBIT rose from £11.7m to £21.5m. Services & Support revenue rose from £190.8m to £218.8m (+9% organically) and EBIT rose from £31.5m to £31.7m.
Well built. As the wider geographic backdrop gets more challenging, so the breadth of its business and balance between OE and Aftermarket accentuate Meggitt's strengths. We are, of course, now accustomed to some volatility in the precise rate of growth in each end market (such as a decline in Regional aircraft and marked lumpiness in the Bizjet AM). In 1H19, the organic growth in revenue for each end market was: Civil OE +11% (FY18 +6%), Civil AM +7% (FY18 +8%), Defence +13% (FY18 +10%), Energy - 1% (FY18 +19%) and Other -14% (FY18 +9%).
Wilderness year. The share price is almost unchanged over 12 months. Perhaps that isn't too bad given the prolonged drag on earnings from the former Polymers & Composites division. After some downward excursions in FY19 to date, we hope the market is now getting to grips with the issue of Free of Charge OE. That Airbus had a backlog of 473 A220 aircraft at end 1H19 and secured commitments for a further 130 A220 aircraft in 1H19 remains unquestionably good news in our eyes. Sure, strong growth in A220 deliveries might just pose some threat to the stated FY21 EBIT margin target of 19.9%, but it isn't a threat to the overall value inherent in Meggitt, in our view.

Tom Dalgleish Any thoughts if CYBG can climb off the canvas?

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 801.00, down 14 (-1.72%), High: 814.00, Low: 796.00, Volume: 1.40m
1966AndAllThat IBM maybe getting a new bosshttps://wccftech.com/exclusive-lisa-su-considers-a-role-beyond-amd-and-prepares-a-successor/
cracklenpop @BE elegantly segued
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Fairly weak H1 makes 2019 a stretch

BE11:35am

Particularly on -- guess what! -- cashflow.

BE11:35am

We're back to the old "Rolls doesn't make any actual money" problem.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Credit Suisse can summarise.

BE11:36am

Unsurprisingly underwhelming FCF in H1 19: FCF came to –GBP391m
for the core of the business and –GBP429m including restructuring costs.
This is below our expectation of –GBP350m. Reduction in OE loss (-0.2m to GBP1.3m per engine) and the growth in flight hours (+8%) has generated positive cash inflow, together with some deposits in Defence. But the cost of the Trent 1000 grounding and the WCR build-up in Civil Aerospace and Power Systems lead to the cash-outflow in H1. The unwind of that WCR in
H2 should allow the group to reach its FY target.

BE11:36am

EBIT lower than expected due to corporate costs: At EBIT level (GBP203m vs our GBP283m anticipation), Civil Aerospace loss was slightly lower than our GB50m forecast (-GBP1m), Power Systems Defence came ahead of our number (favourable R&D phasing) but the corporate charge was larger than we anticipated. Net income underlying is a –GBP24m loss.
■ Trent 1000 behind plan: There are now less than 25 grounded package B & C Trent 1000s and 5-10 Trent-1000 TEN. The pace of decline of the
grounded fleet is "slightly below original plans" and leads to a GBP100m
increase in the expected of in-service costs for the next 2-3 years (GBP50m in 2019 and the remaining GBP50m in 2020 and maybe spreading into 2021). That additional cost is related to the insufficient dimensioning of the MRO network (partly as a result of the TEN issues), which slows the recovery pace and increases overall costs.

Tom Dalgleish RR? Money?
11:36 am
BE11:37am

All clear on the Trent XWB: The Trent XWB performance on-wing remains
extremely high (99.9% dispatch reliability), which is supportive of the long
term ambitions of the group.
■ Guidance is unchanged: It calls for GBP700m +/-GBP100m for both
underlying EBIT and FCF in 2019e. The group also maintains its long-term
objective of GBP1 of FCF per share.
■ Stock reaction: It is as usual difficult to call and we would expect intraday
volatility on the name, depending on where expectations where (there is no
company-compiled consensus and BBG does not list enough estimates).
The stock has been materially weak in recent weeks (-10% vs STOXX6000
YTD, -8% over the last 3m), in part due to market conditions but also on
expectations that H1 would be weak. We find the additional Trent 1000
costs disappointing and the H1 numbers appears underwhelming, but
without being disastrous as the stock behaviour might suggest.

BE11:37am

And UBS.

BE11:37am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
The key number we track for RR is the Core FCF reported at £(391)mn outflow which is
worse than we had expected at £(300)mn. The outflow reflects inventory build-up of
£400mn, compensation payments to Trent1000 and increased level of check and repairs
(295 vs 242 in 1H18) while receivables were up (c.£300m customer advances, mostly from
Defence order wins). This leaves a lot to do in 2H19, but RR mgmt. remains confident it can
deliver £700mn FCF +-£100mn and its 2020 cash target. 2H19 cash should benefit from
higher profit contribution, inventories reduction of "at least £500mn" - £200mn of
inventories unwinding in Aerospace and £200mn in power systems - and £100mn in LTSA
payments. This more than offsets good progress on new engine losses per engine (down
to £1.3mn), 8% growth in the flying hours of large engines which was better than the 6%
we expected. AOGs down from 35 to below 25. Shares have meaningfully
underperformed ahead of results, but the presentation may provide some comfort on
2H2019 cash generation.
Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
Rolls-Royce reported 1H19 group revenues of £7,353m (up 2.2%, UBSe £7,056m),
underlying group EBITA of £203m (+£62m yoy, 2.8% margin, UBSe £222m), EPS of -1.6p
(UBSe 3.5p) . Civil Aerospace revenues came in at £4,018m (up 5.7%, UBSe £3,801m) and
EBITA of -£21m (UBSe -£65m), Defence revenues were £1,494m (up 2.5%, UBSe
£1,457m) and EBITA of £173m (11.6% margin, UBSe £175m), Power Systems revenues
were £1,553m (down 1.3%, UBSe £1,573m) and EBITA of £96m (6.2% margin, UBSe
£101m) and ITP revenues were £457m (up 21.9%, UBSe £375m) and EBITA of £32m
(7.0% margin, UBSe £40m). Capitalised R&D fell slightly yoy which is positive and C&A
costs decreased to 7.2% of sales.
Q: Has the company's guidance changed? No, 2019 outlook was maintained.
2019 outlook has been reiterated. Group FCF guidance for 2019 is £700m (+-£100m),
while underlying revenue is expected to grow at ~10% for Civil Aerospace, mid-single digit
for Power system, stable for Defence, ~10% for ITP Aero. Underlying expected operating
profit for Civil is expected to approach breakeven, Power systems margins are expected to
be around 100bps higher, Defence margins around 100bps lower and ITP aero margins are
expected to be stable. Trent 1000 cash costs are expected to increase by £50m in 2019 and
£50m in 2020.
Valuation: trades on 14.0x 2020e EV/EBITA, 9.3% 2020e FCF yield

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Caz off the conference call.

luzh @shinshin agreed. An easy way to start a social media storm.
BE11:38am

 2020 FCF – mostly wkg cap: RR has a target of £1bn of FCF in 2020. On
the call today it said it expects a £200-300m benefit from “normal wkg cap”
and a £300-400m inflow from prepayments on long-term service
agreements in 2020. This means £500-700m of the 2020 FCF is from wkg
cap items. Many sell-side forecasts have far lower wkg cap inflows than
this. This reaffirms our view that the RR compiled consensus EBITA for
2020 (and probably 2021) is c10% too high. In short, in 2020 there will be
more cash from wkg cap than from profit.
 Reducing market share expectation on Boeing 787: On the call RR said it
expects to maintain a market share of 35% on the Trent 1000. Compare this
to the comment on the FY18 conf call: “On the Trent 1000 …our market
share has declined in terms of new orders and it does set our market share
today is about 35%. We had obviously hoped ahead of this issue that that
share would be growing from mid 30s towards 50%. I would interpret what
happened as a delay in that trajectory.”

BE11:39am

And here's an interesting observation.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Why isn’t RR taking on more FX hedging given such good rates? Indeed
its hedge book fell £2bn over the last six months. We find this very curious
given the upside available to RR from a weaker £. We wonder if the RR
balance sheet is not strong enough to support long-dated FX hedging (we
know that banks require some counter parties to post collateral when they
hedge). On the call today RR said it will be “some time” before it sees any
benefit from better FX.

BE11:40am

JPM also notes that large defence orders padded out FCF by £300m, which are best considered exceptional given the lumpiness.

BE11:41am

JP Morgan really doesn't like Rolls.

A. M. (@1966: had IBM been true to form, it'd been a fresh-faced millennial.)
11:41 am
BE11:42am

RR’s core Civil Aero division is currently loss-making, even using the RR-defined EBITA. Even by 2023/24 we doubt the division can exceed a c8% EBITA margin, meaning it will be significantly less profitable that its European peers.

The RR-defined EBITA is quite low quality in our view as it excludes restructuring & contract charges, and benefits from significant capitalised R&D and from the inclusion of significant royalties that will end in full in 2027.

BE11:42am

We believe that c50% of RR’s cumulative FCF for 2019-22E could be coming from customer advances related to civil aero aftermarket work. If RR performs this work successfully (at a future date) then perhaps c35% of the customer advances will become retained cash for RR and its shareholders.
In 2019 we estimate RR’s adjusted net debt will be greater than £10bn (ie. RR def. net debt/cash + traditional cust. advances + Net Total care creditor (TCC) + op lease liabilities + pension liabilities). We believe the TCC is just another name for a "customer advance".
RR has high execution risk. It is grappling with a £1.5bn cost overrun (2016 to 2021+) related to performance issues with the Trent 1000 engine. In 2018 RR missed its engine delivery targets by 13% (480 deliveries vs. initial guidance of 550).

hagilon @1966AndAllThat , IBM does nothing but lose money in a decade, AMD is emerging as a new company ... I don't know why I should go ... new challenge?

BE11:46am

11:47 am

Starting with Vivendi-Tencent.

11:49 am

Vivendi says it's still talking to other potential partners having previously indicated it would look to sell up to 50%.

BE11:50am

And we get some waffle about commercial cooperation to capture growth opportunities offered by the digitalization and the opening of new markets

A. M. @#REF: amusing (obv not for him) comment from JP, indeed
hagilon @den, is dedicated to manufacturing data centers and HPC and fails to its AI software with watson, NVDA, INTC and AMD take advantage
BE11:51am

Meaning Marshmello gigs on Fortnight or whatever, I guess, because that's the future we're blithely wandering into.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Here comes Goldman.

BE11:52am

We note the following: (1) the implied valuation of UMG (€30 bn) compares with our DCF-based valuation for UMG of €28.9 bn: using the €30 bn valuation in our SOTP with a holdco discount of 5%, would imply a valuation per share for Vivendi of €33. 2) This announcement comes much sooner than we had expected, amid US-China trade tensions, and follows the recent announcement at the 1H19 results that “several contacts have already been established with potential strategic partners”. 3) As discussed in Vivendi: Music & More, we see significant potential benefits for UMG from a strategic commercial partnership with Tencent given the significant market opportunity and UMG’s relatively low market share in China at present. 4) Based on Vivendi’s current market cap, the €30 bn valuation of UMG and the market value of listed stakes implies a negative value for the remaining assets, including Canal+ and Havas.

FATDAZ @den RE IBM I see lots of adds for clod access to their watson super computer
BE11:52am

And Barclays.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

We have €25.8bn in our SOTP for UMG standalone to get to our €26.50 price target. For illustrative purposes, a €30bn valuation would imply a price target of €29.63, implying 24% upside to last night’s close of €23.98 and 12% upside to our price target. Purely as a scenario analysis: assuming that 50% of the proceeds from a 20% Tencent stake are used for a buyback would imply a €30.25 price target, if we also assume in our SOTP that UMG total fair value is €30bn. If we assume that the rest of UMG is valued at €25.8bn (for 100%) – as per our SOTP – then the implied price target using the scenario above would be €26.80. Assuming a 50% buyback following another 20% strategic investor joining (i.e. 40% stake sold) would imply a €31.05 price target based on UMG fair value at €30bn or €27.19 based on the rest of UMG being valued at our SOTP valuation. While a €30bn valuation is not as high as some of the valuations cited in news articles (Reuters, 15 April 2019) we believe this announcement is supportive of the value of UMG in the SOTP – and we believe there was investor doubt on this.

So, on the one hand, this deal goes some way to confirming a relatively high value for UMG – which sceptics did not believe. That is a clear positive to us. On the other hand, 10% is a relatively low proportion, we do not see exactly why Tencent would go to 20% after a year if they haven’t now, and it is not clear to us who else would be interested in a stake at this valuation.

BE11:54am

Speaking with VIV this morning, it was emphasised that the €30bn UMG
equity value is still subject to negotiation. (Presumably linked to the ongoing due diligence.) VIV confirms that UMG has negligible debt, so the indicative €30bn can also be treated as a prelim enterprise value. We believe that market estimates of UMG's EV range between €17bn and €44bn (with JEF at €21bn). Against that backdrop, the prelim value announced today looks strong. An important caveat is that the €30bn EV applies to only a small stake. There is no evidence of conditions that would oblige TME to exercise its call option on the further 10%.
Two connected deals? It is unclear if the stake sale depends on the parallel
commercial deal with TME and what economic transfers this deal involves. TME's emergence as a strategic buyer comes at an opportune time with the stake sale process entering a 2nd year. Accepting that TME is the gatekeeper for entry into China, we think clarification is required as to how any commercial deal with TME may constrain (or enhance) UMG's opportunities for value creation in China over the long-term.
Residual minority. Prospects of monetising the residual minority stake in UMG could be influenced by the presence of TME as a s/holder wielding material influence and the nature of any commercial agreements signed with TME. Untangling these details would be crucial for a follow-up investor in UMG, in our view. A subsequent minority stake may, therefore, be valued differently. VIV has previously ruled out an IPO for monetising a UMG stake.

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Group 2Q RevPAR was -0.2% (UBSe 0.9%, 1Q19 0.3%), with 1H 2018 revenues (ex-system) of $1,012m (UBS $995m vs cons $1,000m, 1H18 $900m). Adj. EBITA was $410m (UBSe $407m, cons $410m, 1H18 $413m) and net income $267m (UBSe $262m, 1H18 $271m).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Q2 RevPAR in Americas -0.5% (UBSe 1%), EMEAA +0.7% (UBSe 1%) and Greater China -0.5% (UBSe 0%). Net c19k rooms opened in 1H, +5.7% yoy, the highest growth in over a decade (vs UBSe FY19 +5.1%), and pipeline now c282k. IHG has c856k rooms.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: IHG remains confident in its FY outlook. Consensus and UBSe FY adjusted EBITA c$875m. IHG says it remains on track to deliver c$125m in annual savings by 2020.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: While RevPAR was weak, overall results are in line with consensus and net system growth was strong.

And RBC, also to summarise.

BE11:59am

InterContinental Hotels Group | IHG LN | Underperform | Current price 5289p | Price Target 4500p

H1 19 Results – Weak RevPAR, Profits in-line when adjusted for system fund

Summary
IHG reports 0.1% RevPAR growth for H1 19. Looking at this regionally, the group saw +0.1% in the Americas, +0.2% in EMEAA and -0.3% in Greater China. We forecast 0.9% for the full year.

Profit metrics came in line with expectations when adjusted for the System Fund. EBITDA was $466m (consensus $450m & RBCe $448m) and EBIT at $410m (consensus & RBCe at $409m). PBT came in at $375m vs RBC expectations of $285m, but $335m pre the cost from the system fund. H1 fee margin was down 20bps (down 30bps at CER), held back by the acquisition of Six Senses and by $6m of cost phasing benefit in H1 2018. Excluding these impacts, fee margin increased +130bps (+110bps at CER).

The group showed net system growth of +5.7%, the highest in over a decade, with 30k room additions. It removed 10k rooms, leaving 856k across the estate. The total pipeline now stands at 282k rooms with first half signings of 48k including a record performance in Greater China.

Mgmt. don’t expect any change to consensus.

12:13 pm
BE12:13pm

Genel reported H1 financial results a little ahead of our forecasts on a pre working capital basis. The strong H1 results demonstrate the FCF generation potential of the business. On an underlying basis (after adjusting for a monthly payment received on 9th July) H1 FCF of US$76m equates to an annualised FCF yield of ~20%. We forecast Genel can deliver a 17% pa FCF yield over the 5 years to 2023 at US$60/bbl Brent, rising to 24% pa at US$75/bbl, driven largely by producing assets. We see the potential for strong FCF generation to the end of the next decade. The financial strength of the business is underlined with confirmation of an interim dividend of 5c/sh, taking the total dividend thus far this year to 15c/sh (~11.5p/sh, ~6.5% yield at current prices). Genel trades at 0.59x our discovered resource NAV, a small discount to the sector on 0.62. Genel’s cash generation is less geared to oil price than peers; at US$60/bbl Brent Genel trades at 0.74x NAV, a sizeable 17% discount to the peer group on 0.89x. We retain our Buy rating and 300p target price.
● Strong financial performance: Revenues of US$194m were US$11m (6%) ahead of our US$184m estimate. Partially offsetting this, operating costs of US$18m were US$4m (25%) ahead of our US$14m estimate owing to additional trucking costs at Peshkabir, which should be eliminated during H2 once a pipeline is commissioned.
EBITDAX of US$167m was US$13m (8%) ahead of our US$155m forecast. Operating CF (pre W/C) of US$168m was US$11m (7%) ahead of our US$157m forecast. Post a US$25m W/C outflow, op CF was US$14m below our forecast, however, US$19m of the w/c movement relates to a delayed monthly payment for Tawke which was received on 9 July. FCF pre w/c of US$82.5m was in-line with our US$81.7m forecast.

but this is in-line with our prior forecast of US$166m (now US$171m).
● Key operations on track: Work has commenced at Sarta, with first production on schedule for mid 2020. The Qara Dagh appraisal well is on track to spud in H1 2020. Negotiations are ongoing between Genel and the Kurdistan Regional Government regarding the commercial terms for a staged, integrated oil and gas development at Bina Bawi. There is now alignment on a Ph1 upstream project scope which involves use of cash-flow from the oil to fund the initial midstream facilities.
